metadata.title: The coronavirus proofreading exoribonuclease mediates extensive viral recombination 1 2

abstract.text: 20 Coronaviruses (CoVs) emerge as zoonoses and cause severe disease in humans, 21 demonstrated by the SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pandemic. RNA recombination is 22 required during normal CoV replication for subgenomic mRNA (sgmRNA) synthesis and 23 . CC-BY

body_text.text: generates defective viral genomes (DVGs) of unknown function. However, the 24 determinants and patterns of CoV recombination are unknown. Here, we show that 25 divergent b-CoVs SARS-CoV-2, MERS-CoV, and murine hepatitis virus (MHV) perform 26 extensive RNA recombination in culture, generating similar patterns of recombination 27 junctions and diverse populations of DVGs and sgmRNAs. We demonstrate that the 28 CoV proofreading nonstructural protein (nsp14) 3'-to-5' exoribonuclease (nsp14-ExoN) 29

is required for normal CoV recombination and that its genetic inactivation causes 30 significantly decreased frequency and altered patterns of recombination in both infected 31 cells and released virions. Thus, nsp14-ExoN is a key determinant of both high fidelity 32

CoV replication and recombination, and thereby represents a highly-conserved and 33 vulnerable target for virus inhibition and attenuation. 34 abundance of MHV sgmRNA2 (Eckerle et al., 2007) and altered human CoV 229E 93 (HCoV-229E) sgmRNA detection during viral recovery (Minskaia et al., 2006) . These 94 studies suggest that nsp14-ExoN RNA proofreading activity of CoVs may play a key 95 role in RNA recombination in addition to known functions in replication fidelity, viral 96 fitness and virulence, resistance to nucleoside analogs, and immune antagonism ( We performed direct RNA Nanopore sequencing on the same RNA used for short-read 185 RNA-seq. For both viruses, three independent sequencing experiments were performed 186 on triplicate samples of 2 µg RNA for each virus. In order to remove prematurely 187 truncated sequences, we bioinformatically filtered for Nanopore reads containing both 188 genomic termini. Capture and sequencing of sgmRNAs and DVGs resulted in high 189 sequencing coverage at both ends of the genome, while the relatively poorer capture of 190 full-length genomes was limited due to their extreme length and resulting in depleted 191 coverage in the middle of the genome (Figure 2A -B). We sequenced 132,493 MERS-192

CoV RNA molecules and 1,725,862 SARS-CoV-2 RNA molecules that had 85.6% and 193 82.2% identity to the parental genome, respectively (Table S1 ). We obtained 3 full-194 length direct RNA sequences of the SARS-CoV-2 genome containing over 29, 850 195 consecutive nucleotides that aligned to the SARS-CoV-2 genome (Table S2 ). In CoV RNA, we detected 451 unique junction-containing full-length molecules (Figure 2A , 197 Table S3 ). SARS-CoV-2 RNA contained distinct 172,191 junction-containing molecules 198 ( Figure 2B , Table S2 ). 199

To define the architectures of detected molecules, we filtered for junctions with at least 201 3 supporting Nanopore reads. In MERS-CoV, we defined 5 distinct species, including 3 202 sgmRNAs (6, 7, and 8) and 2 DVGs ( Figure 2C ). In SARS-CoV-2, there were 1166 203 isoforms with a single junction and 227 containing 2 junctions. Because the TRS 204 sequences and sgmRNA species have not previously been experimentally confirmed in 205 SARS-CoV-2, a Nanopore read was categorized as a predicted sgmRNA transcript if it 206 had a junction between the predicted 5' TRS-L and the predicted structural and 207 . The 15 most abundant isoforms in SARS-CoV-2 included 7 predicted sgmRNA 209 transcripts and 8 DVGs ( Figure 2D ). We also identified potential alternative transcripts 210 corresponding to a single gene (ORF8) ( Figure 2D ). In summary, direct RNA Nanopore (Table S4) Table S4 ). In virions, MHV-ExoN(-) has significantly increased recombination in nsp3, 278 nsp4, and two positions in nsp12 ( Figure S4B -C, Table S4 ). In addition, MHV-ExoN(-) 279 has significantly increased recombination at one position within the 3' untranslated 280 region (3'-UTR) ( Figure S4E , Table S4 ). Table S1, Table S2, and Table S3 . FIGREF0.text: Case 97 et al., 2017; Ferron et al., 2018a; Graepel et al., 2019). 98 99 In this study, we sought to define the frequency and patterns of recombination of 100 divergent b-CoVs SARS-CoV-2, MERS-CoV, and MHV. We show that all three viruses 101 perform extensive recombination during replication in vitro, with broadly similar patterns 102 of recombination, generating diverse populations of recombined molecules. We further 103 demonstrate that genetically engineered inactivation of MHV nsp14-ExoN activity 104 results in a significant decrease in recombination frequency, altered recombination 105 junction patterns across the genome, and altered junction site selection. These defects 106 and alterations result in a marked change in MHV-ExoN(-) recombined RNA 107 populations, including defective viral genomes (DVGs). Previous studies our lab and 108 others confirm the requirement of ExoN activity in high-fidelity replication, exclusion of 109 aberrant nucleotides, viral fitness, and virulence (Eckerle et al., 2007, 2007; Ferron et 110 al., 2018a; Graham et al., 2012). Combined with the multiple critical integrated functions 111 recombination junctions as well as description of the genetic architectures of molecules 139 formed by the junctions. 140 141 For RNA-seq, we generated libraries in triplicate from 2 µg samples of both MERS-CoV 142 and SARS-CoV-2 infected cells. Reads were aligned to the respective viral genomes 143 using a recombination-aware mapper, ViReMa (Virus Recombination Mapper) (Routh 144 and Johnson, 2014). ViReMa detects non-homologous recombination events resulting 145 in subgenomic mRNAs (sgmRNAs) and defective viral genomes (DVGs) by identifying 146 recombination junctions that generate a deletion greater than 5 base-pairs flanked on 147 both sides by a 25 base-pair alignment. ViReMa aligned both recombined and non-148 recombined reads in the library and reported the total number of nucleotides aligned to 149 the genome and all detected recombination junctions (Figure S1A-B). 150 151 MERS-CoV RNA contained an average of 19,367 detected junctions per dataset and 152 SARS-CoV-2 libraries had an average of 56,082 detected junctions per dataset. To 153 normalize for variations in library size between samples, recombination junction 154 frequency (Jfreq) was calculated for MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 (Figure 1B). Jfreq 155 refers to the number of nucleotides in all detected junctions normalized to total mapped 156 nucleotides in a library. MERS-CoV had a mean Jfreq of 37.80 junctions detected per SARS-CoV-2 displayed clusters of junctions between the 5' and 3' ends of the genome, 162 intermediate genomic positions and the 3' end of the genome, and within the 3' end of 163 the genome (Figure 1B-C). SARS-CoV-2 also had many low-frequency junctions 164 distributed across the genome, a major cluster of junctions representing local deletions 165 and between the 5' UTR and the rest of the genome, and horizontal clusters of low-166 frequency junctions between common start sites at position ~2000 and ~8000 and the 167 rest of the genome (Figure 1D). Overall, these data demonstrate that extensive RNA 168 recombination in both MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 generates diverse populations of 169 junctions with similar high-abundance clusters. 170 171 To determine whether high-frequency recombination occurs randomly across MERS-172 CoV and SARS-CoV-2 genomes, we calculated mean positional recombination 173 frequency (Figure 1E-F) by comparing the number of nucleotides in detected junctions 174 (both start and stop sites) at that position normalized to nucleotide depth at that 175 position. The first and last 5000 nucleotides of both MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 176 genomes showed clusters of recombination (Figure 1E-F). SARS-CoV-2 had many 177 peaks of recombination frequency of greater than 0.50 (50%) across the genome 178 (Figure 1F), suggesting that SARS-CoV-2 generates a diverse set of RNA molecules 179 with distinct genetic architectures through recombination. 180 181 Direct RNA Nanopore sequencing of MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 defines the 182 architecture of full-length genome, subgenomic RNAs, and defective viral 183

FIGREF1.text: 211 sequencing defined a diverse set of recombined RNAs generated by both MERS-CoV 212 and SARS-CoV-2. The results confirmed and extended the short-read RNA-seq 213 datasets. Our results are likely an underestimate of total numbers and diversity based 214 on the conservative bioinformatic limitation of analysis to isoforms with at least 3 215 supporting reads. Thus, both MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 engage in extensive RNA 216 recombination during replication in cell culture, producing diverse junctions across the 217 viral genomes and many recombined RNA isoforms, with the indication that SARS-CoV-218 2 recombination exceeds that of MERS-CoV in Vero cells. These findings underline the 219 importance of defining the determinants of CoV recombination. 220 221 The b-coronavirus murine hepatitis virus (MHV) lacking nsp14-ExoN activity has 222 significantly decreased and altered distribution of RNA recombination events. In 223 picornaviruses and alphaviruses, recombination is regulated by determinants of 224 replication fidelity (Kempf et al., 2016; Li et al., 2019; Poirier et al., 2015; Woodman et 225 al., 2018). CoVs encode a 3'-5' exoribonuclease (ExoN) in non-structural protein 14 226 (nsp14) that regulates replication fidelity by RNA proofreading (Eckerle et al., 2007; 227 Ferron et al., 2018b; Minskaia et al., 2006). No proofreading-deficient nsp14-ExoN 228 catalytic mutant has been rescued in MERS-CoV or SARS-CoV-2. We have rescued 229 and extensively studied ExoN catalytic inactivation mutants (ExoN(-)) in b-CoVs murine 230 (MHV) and SARS-CoV. We used MHV and compared an engineered 231 ExoN catalytic inactivation mutant (MHV-ExoN(-)) to wild-type virus (MHV-WT). Murine 232 delayed brain tumor cells (DBT-9) were infected in triplicate with either MHV-WT or 233 MHV-ExoN(-) at an MOI of 0.01 pfu/mL and total infected cell monolayer RNA was 234 extracted when the monolayer was 95% involved in cytopathic effect and >75% intact. 235 To isolate virions, DBT-9 cell were infected in triplicate with either MHV-WT or MHV-236 ExoN(-) at an MOI of 0.01 pfu/mL and virions were isolated by ultracentrifugation from 237 supernatant collected when the monolayer was 95% involved in cytopathic effect and 238 >90% intact. RNA-seq datasets were aligned to the MHV genome using ViReMa, 239 reporting the genomic coverage in infected cells (Figure S2A-B) and virions (Figure 240

FIGREF2.text: S3A-B). To determine whether loss of nsp14-ExoN activity alters recombination, we 241 quantified recombination junction frequency (Jfreq) in MHV-WT and MHV-ExoN(-). We 242 found that MHV-ExoN(-) had significantly decreased Jfreq relative to MHV-WT in both 243 infected cells (Figure 3B) and virions (Figure 3D).244 245 We next tested whether loss of nsp14-ExoN activity altered the population of junction 246 sites. Recombination junctions detected by ViReMa were plotted according to their start 247 (5') and stop (3') sites in infected cell RNA (Figure 3C, Figure S2C-D) and virion RNA 248 (Figure 3E, Figure S3C-D). MHV-WT displayed clusters of junctions (i) between the 5' 249 and 3' ends of the genome, (ii) between intermediate genomic positions and the 3' end 250 of the genome, (iii) between the 5' UTR and the rest of the genome, (iv) in local 251 deletions across the genome, and (v) within the 3' end of the genome (Figure 3C and 252 3E). Similarly, MHV-ExoN(-) accumulated junction clusters between the 5' and 3' ends 253 genome and within the 3' end of the genome (Figure 3C and 3E). However, MHV-254 ExoN(-) had fewer junctions between the 5' UTR and the rest of the genome and fewer 255 junctions forming local deletions (Figure 3C and 3E). Together, these findings show that 256 loss of MHV nsp14-ExoN activity resulted in decreased recombination frequency and 257 altered junction patterns across the genome. 258 259 Loss of nsp14-ExoN activity alters recombination in distinct genomic regions. To 260 determine whether the engineered defect in nsp14-ExoN alters recombination across 261 the genome, we calculated and compared mean positional recombination frequencies of 262 MHV-WT (blue) and MHV-ExoN(-) (orange) in both infected cell monolayers (Figure 4A) 263 and virions (Figure 4B). MHV-WT has high recombination frequency at the 5' and 3' 264 ends of the genome as well as at distinct sites across the genome. MHV-ExoN(-) has a 265 similar distribution in both infected cells and virus particles (Figure 4A-B). There were 266 765 positions in infected cell RNA and 499 positions in virion RNA

FIGREF3.text: with 267 significantly altered recombination frequency in MHV-ExoN(-) compared to MHV-WT. 268 These differences are best illustrated when the distinct genomic regions are separately 269 visualized (Figure S4). 270 271 In the 5' UTR, nucleotides within the TRS-leader (TRS-L, yellow) participate in 272 recombination junctions in both MHV-WT and MHV-ExoN(-) as expected, although 273 MHV-ExoN(-) has significantly decreased recombination frequency at all sites within the 274 TRS-L (Figure S4A, Table S4). Both MHV-WT and MHV-ExoN(-) display recombination 275 across the nonstructural proteins, although MHV-ExoN(-) demonstrates overall 276

FIGREF4.text: ExoN(-) has decreased subgenomic mRNA populations and increased 283 abundance of defective viral genomes. We next determined whether loss of nsp14-284 ExoN activity influences sgmRNA patterns and abundance, as proposed in earlier 285 studies (Eckerle et al., 2007; Minskaia et al., 2006). We quantified recombination 286 junction frequencies (Jfreq) of each of the known junctions formed between the common 287 TRS-L and 6 sgmRNA-specific body TRSs. sgmRNA Jfreq refers to the number of 288 nucleotides corresponding to the sgmRNA leader-body junction normalized to mapped 289 library size. sgmRNAs 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 were significantly decreased in MHV-ExoN(-) 290 infected cell RNA (Figure 4C). sgmRNA 4 and 6 were present at significantly decreased 291 frequencies in MHV-ExoN(-) virions compared to MHV-WT (Figure 4D). Thus, MHV-292 ExoN(-) has altered frequency of multiple sgmRNAs both in infected cells and in virus 293 particles. 294 295 We further defined alterations to different populations of recombined RNA molecules in 296 MHV-ExoN(-) compared to MHV-WT by quantifying the percentages of sgmRNA and 297 DVG junctions in the total population of detected junctions. Any junction that did not 298 form a canonical leader-body TRS junction was considered a DVG junction, likely 299 of previously undefined non-canonical or alternative sgmRNA 300 junctions. The percentage of sgmRNA junctions were significantly decreased and the 301 percentage of DVG junctions significantly increased in both infected cell RNA (Figure 3024E) and virion RNA (Figure 4F). These findings demonstrate that loss of nsp14-ExoN 303 activity alters the locations at which the replicase machinery recombines across the 304 genome, resulting in both decreased and altered sgmRNAs and relatively increased 305 percentage of DVGs in MHV-ExoN(-) compared to MHV-WT. Thus, catalytic inactivation 306 of nsp14-ExoN results in a defect in recombination site selection. 307 308 Differential abundance of recombination junctions in MHV-ExoN(-) reveals altered 309 recombination junction site selection. We next defined the distribution of 310 recombination junctions with altered abundance in MHV-ExoN(-) compared to MHV-WT. 311 We quantified the abundance junctions identified over three independent experiments 312 and identified junction populations with altered abundances in MHV-ExoN(-) compared 313 to MHV-WT using DESeq2 (Love et al., 2014). MHV-ExoN(-) RNA contained distinct 314 junction populations with both significantly increased and decreased abundance relative 315 to MHV-WT in infected cells (Figure S5A,Table S5) and in virus particles (Figure S5B, 316Table S5). We mapped significantly altered junctions by their genomic position (Figure 317

FIGREF5.text: 4G-H). Recombination junctions enriched in MHV-ExoN(-) were mainly found between 318 the 5' and 3' ends of the genome (Figure 4G-H). This observation suggests that MHV-319 ExoN(-) is accumulating altered populations of DVGs that are formed by these 320 decreased abundance in MHV-ExoN(-) compared to MHV-WT in both 323 infected cells (Figure 4G) and virions (Figures 4H) mainly clustered between the 5' UTR 324 and the rest of the genome. Further, infected cell RNA demonstrates a cluster of 325 junctions with decreased abundance in MHV-ExoN(-) in the 3' end of the genome that 326 represent local deletions in this region (Figure 4G). This finding was complemented by 327 the cluster of decreased abundance of local deletions of 10 -50 bp in length across the 328 genome in MHV-ExoN(-) virion RNA (Figure 4H). Together, these findings demonstrate 329 that the populations of recombination junctions that were differentially abundant in MHV-330 ExoN(-) were not randomly distributed across the genome. This suggests that loss of 331 nsp14-ExoN activity results in altered recombination site selection in distinct regions of 332 the genome. 333 334 Direct RNA Nanopore sequencing identifies defects in MHV-ExoN(-) full-length 335 recombined RNA populations. To test the alterations of full-length recombined RNAs 336 due to loss of nsp14-ExoN proofreading activity, we sequenced MHV-WT and MHV-337 ExoN(-) virion RNA by direct RNA Nanopore sequencing. Reads were mapped to the 338 MHV genome using minimap2 and mapped reads containing both genomic termini were 339 identified. MHV-WT virion RNA contained 101,714 complete molecules and MHV-340 ExoN(-) virion RNA yielded 19,334 (Table S1). Reads mapping to the full-length 341 parental genome were not observed, likely due to the length (31.4 kb) of the MHV 342 genome, and datasets yielded only sgmRNAs and DVGs. MHV-ExoN(-) consistently 343 demonstrated ~1 log10 reduction in nucleotide depth at positions across the genome 344 relative to MHV-WT (Figure 5A). This finding directly corroborated the decreased 345 fewer full-length molecules sequenced, MHV-ExoN(-) had a global 349 decrease in the number of junctions across the genome (Figure 5B). Because 350 molecules with multiple junctions in a single molecule were detected but not supported 351 by more than one read, they were excluded from downstream analyses. We next 352 mapped junctions detected in full-length RNA molecules according to their genomic 353 position (Figure 5C). While MHV-WT contains 852 unique junctions present in full-length 354 molecules, MHV-ExoN(-) had only 43 (Table S3). MHV-WT recombination junctions 355 exclusively connect positions in the first ~8,000 nucleotides of the genome to the 3' UTR 356 (Figure 5C). MHV-ExoN(-) had fewer junction sites, none of which represented distinct 357 clusters (Figure 5D). We next grouped junctions within 10-base pair windows to define 358 distinct families of molecules supported by at least three reads. Nine such architectures 359 were identified in MHV-WT (Figure 5E). These populations contain both DVGs and 360 sgmRNAs. The four most abundant isoforms were also detected in MHV-ExoN(-) virion 361 RNA, which corresponded to a DVG and sgmRNAs 4,6 and 7 (Figure 5E). We did not 362 detect MHV-ExoN(-)-unique variants with at least 3 supporting reads, potentially due to 363 their low frequency in the population and the limited depth of Nanopore sequencing. 364 Additionally, all junctions generating RNA molecules found in MHV-WT and MHV-365 ExoN(-) were present in short-read RNA-seq datasets. These data demonstrate that 366 loss of nsp14-ExoN activity drives the accumulation altered recombined RNA 367 populations and DVG species diversity. study, we define the diversity of the CoV recombination landscape in MHV, 371 MERS-CoV, and SARS-CoV-2. We also demonstrate that the loss of nsp14-ExoN 372 activity in MHV results in decreased recombination and alters site selection of 373 recombination junctions. Our results support a model in which nsp14-ExoN activity 374 functions during replication to drive normal recombination, leading to the generation of 375 populations of discrete molecules, including sgmRNAs and DVGs. 376 377 MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have extensive recombination networks producing 378 diverse populations of RNA species. We show that both MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-379 2, the etiological agent of the ongoing global pandemic of COVID-19, performs 380 extensive recombination and generates diverse populations of RNA molecules. SARS-381 CoV-2 demonstrated relatively increased recombination frequency compared to MERS-382 CoV and displayed unique clusters of recombination junctions across the SARS-CoV-2 383 genome. We analyzed SARS-CoV-2 propagated from a clinical isolate that had been 384 passaged in cell culture, while MERS-CoV was generated from an isogenic clone of low 385 passage. It is possible that the differences could be the result of the diversity and 386 composition of the original sample or propagation in different cell types. Alternatively, 387 these differences may be due to alterations in transcription and RNA synthesis kinetics 388 in SARS-CoV-2 compared to MERS-CoV, which have not been previously defined. It 389 will be important for future studies to determine the role of the diversity of the viral 390 population, cell environment, and virus-specific RNA synthesis kinetics in viral 391 Nanopore sequencing on the Oxford Nanopore Technologies MinION 395 platform has sequenced sgmRNAs and DVGs in the alpha-coronavirus human 396 coronavirus 229E (HCoV-229E) (Viehweger et al., 2019) and has been utilized to 397 identify putative sgmRNAs in SARS-CoV-2 (Kim et al., 2020; Taiaroa et al., 2020). 398 Direct RNA Nanopore sequencing further revealed the profound diversity of RNA 399 species produced by SARS-CoV-2 during infection and yielded the first reported full-400 length, continuous direct RNA reads of SARS-CoV-2. The full-length genome 401 sequences are currently the longest and most complete direct RNA Nanopore 402 sequences reported for any CoV. Detection of multiple RNA molecules with similar but 403 distinct genetic architectures corresponding to a single open reading frame suggests 404 that SARS-CoV-2 produces alternative transcripts. Tandem genetic and proteomic 405 studies of sgmRNA species in SARS-CoV-2 will be valuable to experimentally define 406 populations of translated SARS-CoV-2 sgmRNAs their role in viral replication. 407 408Murine hepatitis virus (MHV) incorporates diverse recombinant RNA in its virions. 409Comparison of recombination in MHV-infected cells and virus particles (virions)410 revealed that the observed recombination patterns and species generated in infected 411 cells are largely retained in virions. Specifically, we observed three previously 412 unexpected recombination junction clusters: (1) junctions connecting the canonical 5' 413 TRS-L to non-canonical positions across the genome; (2) junctions representing small 414 of the genome, including structural proteins and the 3' UTR. This result was 416 surprising based on earlier studies reporting the requirement of specific packaging 417 signals for incorporation of select RNA species into the virions (Kuo and Masters, 2013). 418 Our direct RNA Nanopore sequencing studies show that MHV virions contain a diverse 419 population of recombined RNA molecules which exclude the canonical MHV packaging 420 signal at position 20,273 -20,367 (Kuo and Masters, 2013). Thus, MHV may have 421 much lower barriers for packaging a diverse population of RNA species than previously 422 known, which may aid in the transmission and accumulation of DVGs even under low-423 MOI conditions. 424 425 MHV lacking nsp14-ExoN activity has globally decreased and altered 426 recombination. MHV-ExoN(-) demonstrated a global decrease in recombination 427 junction frequency in both infected cells and virions while also exhibiting skewed 428 populations of sgmRNAs, an increased proportion of DVGs, and altered populations of 429 recombinant isoforms. Our findings demonstrate a novel role for nsp14-ExoN in CoV 430 RNA recombination and further suggest that loss of nsp14-ExoN activity results in 431 altered recombination site selection. Decreased recombination frequency at canonical 432 TRSs in MHV-ExoN(-) suggest that there is decreased accumulation of sgmRNAs. This 433 finding is supported by previous studies (Eckerle et al., 2007; Minskaia et al., 2006) that 434 report a defect in MHV-ExoN(-) sgmRNA synthesis. Perturbation of the abundance of 435 each sgmRNA will likely have a profound influence on the fitness and virulence of CoVs 436 as sgmRNAs encode critical viral proteins including nucleocapsid (N), spike (S), and 437 ExoN(-) virion RNA demonstrates a significant increase in recombination in five 441 distinct genomic regions: 1) nsp3, 2) nsp4, 3) nsp12, 4) the spike (S) protein, and 5) the 442 3' UTR. Previous studies show that CoV DVGs frequently contain sequences from the 443 first replicase proteins after the 5' UTR (Kim et al.; Makino; Makino et al., 1984, 1988; 444 Penzes et al., 1996). Increased recombination in nsp3 and nsp4 may be the result of 445 altered DVG formation and increased accumulation in virus particles. Some of the 446 detected DVGs may be non-canonical sgmRNAs, containing junctions near the TRSs 447 and potentially encode novel translation reading frames (Di et al., 2017; Viehweger et 448 al., 2019). 449 450 Loss of MHV nsp14-ExoN activity results in altered recombination site selection. 451 Differential abundance analysis, mapping of junction detected in multiple experiments, 452 and direct RNA Nanopore sequencing suggest that defective nsp14-ExoN activity drives 453 altered recombination site selection resulting in different populations of accumulated 454 molecules. In this model, abrogation of nsp14-ExoN activity would cause altered 455 replicase activity, resulting in selection of aberrant sites, potentially based on sequence 456 or structural elements. In both picornaviruses and alphaviruses, low fidelity mutant 457 viruses have altered polymerase speed and processivity (Campagnola et al., 2015) and 458 these properties contribute to recombination and the generation of defective interfering 459 particles (Kim et al., 2019; Langsjoen et al., 2020; Poirier et al., 2015). The MHV-ExoN(-may have altered protein-protein interactions that change the stability of the 461 complex and drive altered site selection. Alternatively, loss of nsp14-ExoN activity may 462 result in defective replicase-RNA interactions and therefore cause altered RNA 463 recombination site selection. In both models, nsp14-ExoN activity is an important 464 determinant of replicase activity during RNA synthesis and recombination. However, 465 there are likely other determinants of recombination in the CoV replicase that will be 466 important to define through future genetic and structure-function studies. 467 468 In this study, we identify key positions across the genome that are involved in 469 recombination junctions in the model b-CoV, MHV and we establish nsp14-ExoN 470 proofreading activity as a key determinant of recombination in b-CoVs. Our previous 471 studies of MHV nsp14-ExoN findings genetics and functions have been directly 472 reproduced in SARS-CoV (Agostini et al., 2018; Eckerle et al., 2010; Smith et al., 2013). 473 Thus, we would predict that SARS-CoV-2, will demonstrate the requirement of nsp14-474 ExoN activity for recombination. Further, treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection with small 475 molecules that target the replicase proteins including nsp14-ExoN may result in an 476 altered recombination landscape and perturb viral fitness. It will be important for future 477 studies to assess the role of RNA proofreading, replication fidelity, and small molecule 478 antivirals in recombination of SARS-CoV-2. Understanding the relationship between 479 protein determinants in RNA recombination will provide new targets for countermeasure 480 development to combat emergence of novel CoVs from animal reservoirs with 481 members of the Denison laboratory for insightful discussions regarding this 485 study. This work was supported by National Institutes of Health grants R01AI108197 486 (M.R.D.), T32GM065086 (J.G.), F31AI133952 (M.L.A). We are grateful for support from 487 the Dolly Parton COVID-19 Research Fund, the Vanderbilt University Office of 488 Research, and the Elizabeth B. Lamb Center for Pediatric Research at M.R.D, J.D.C., J.G.); supervision (M.R.D., A.L.R.), project 493 administration (M.R.D., A.L.R.), funding acquisition (M.R.D., J.D.C., A.J.P.), MHV 494 infections and deep sequencing of MHV, MERS-CoV, and SARS-CoV (J.G.), MERS-495 CoV infections (L.J.S.), SARS-CoV-2 infections (L.J.S), SARS-CoV-2 RNA isolation 496 (X.L.), Nanopore sequencing (J.G.), bioinformatic analysis and visualization (J.G.), 497 software development (J.G., A.L.R.), data curation (J.G.), writing (J.G.)

FIGREF6.text: Genome-wide recombination generates populations of diverse RNA 506 molecules in MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2. (A) Genome organization of MERS-CoV 507 (violet) and SARS-CoV-2 (gray). Nonstructural (nsps 1 -16) and structural (S, E, M, N) 508 and accessory open reading frames (ORFs) are labelled. The common 5' leader 509 transcription leader sequence (TRS-L) is denoted with an unfilled red star. Body TRSs 510 are labelled with filled red stars. MERS-CoV total cell lysates (black) and SARS-CoV-2 511 infected cell monolayers (violet) were sequenced by RNA-seq. (B) Junction frequency 512 (Jfreq) was calculated by comparing the number of nucleotides in ViReMa-detected 513 junctions to all mapped nucleotides. Error bars represent standard errors of the mean 514 for three independent sequencing libraries (N = 3). Recombination junctions are 515 mapped according to their genomic position (5' junction site, Start Position; 3' junction 516 site, Stop Position) and colored according to their frequency in the population of all 517 junctions in MERS-CoV (C) and SARS-CoV-2 (D). The highest frequency junctions are 518 magenta and completely opaque. The lowest frequency junctions are red and the most 519 transparent. Dashed boxes represent clusters of junctions: (i) 5' à 3'; (ii) mid-genome 520 à 3' UTR; (iii) 3' à 3'; (iv) local deletions; (v) 5' UTR à rest of genome. Recombination 521 frequency is quantified across the MERS-CoV (E) and SARS-CoV-2 (F) genomes. 522 Recombination frequency is represented as a mean of three independent sequencing 523 libraries (N = 3). See also Figure S1. 524 Direct RNA Nanopore sequencing of MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 526 reveals accumulation of distinct recombined RNA populations. Direct RNA 527 Nanopore sequencing of poly-adenylated MERS-CoV total cell lysates and SARS-CoV-cell monolayer RNA. Three sequencing experiments were performed for each 529 virus. Nanopore reads passing quality control were combined and mapped to the viral 530 genome using minimap2. Full-length reads containing the genomic termini were 531 identified by bioinformatic filtering. Genome coverage maps and Sashimi plots 532 visualizing junctions (arcs) in full-length (A) MERS-CoV (black) and (B) SARS-CoV-2 533 (violet) RNA reads. (C) Distinct RNA molecules identified in MERS-CoV (black) with at 534 least 3 supporting reads are visualized. The number of sequenced reads containing the 535 junction is listed (Count). Genetic sequences of each RNA molecule are represented by 536 filled boxes and deleted regions are noted (Deleted Region(s)) and represented by 537 dashed lines. Molecules containing junctions between the MERS-CoV TRS sequences 538 are listed as sgmRNAs. (D) The 15 most abundant SARS-CoV-2 (violet) recombined 539 RNA molecules and 3 full-genome reads are visualized. Molecules containing junctions 540 linking the 5' UTR and the predicted open reading frames of structural and accessory 541 proteins are listed as predicted sgmRNAs. See also

FIGREF7.text: Loss of nsp14-ExoN activity decreases recombination frequency and 544 alters recombination junction patterns across the genome. (A) Genome 545 organization of MHV. Nonstructural (nsps 1 -16) and structural (S, E, M, N) and 546 accessory open reading frames (ORFs) are labelled. The common 5' leader 547 transcription leader sequence (TRS-L) is denoted with an unfilled red star. Body TRSs 548 are labelled with filled red stars. Infected monolayer and virion RNA from independent 549 experiments were poly(A) selected, sequenced by RNA-seq, and aligned to the MHV 550 genome using ViReMa. Junction frequency (Jfreq) in infected monolayer RNA (B) and 551 (D) was calculated by dividing the number of sequenced nucleotides in all 552 junctions by the total number of nucleotides sequenced in the library. Error bars 553 represent standard error of the means (SEM) (N = 3). Statistical significance was 554 determined by the unpaired student's t-test. *, p < 0.05. Unique forward (5' à 3') 555 recombination junctions detected in infected monolayers (C) and virions (E) were 556 mapped in MHV-WT and MHV-ExoN(-) according to their genomic position. Junctions 557 are colored according to their frequency in the population (high frequency = magenta; 558 low frequency = red). Clusters are marked by dashed boxes: (i) 5' à 3'; (ii) mid-genome 559 à 3'; (iii) 3' à 3'; (iv) local deletions; (v) 5' UTR à rest of genome. See also Figure S2, Loss of nsp14-ExoN alters recombination at multiple genomic loci and 563 skews recombined RNA populations. Mean recombination frequency at each position 564 across the MHV genome was compared in MHV-WT (blue) and MHV-ExoN(-) (orange) 565 infected monolayer (A) and virion RNA (B). Positions with significantly altered 566 recombination frequencies were identified by a 2-way ANOVA with multiple 567 comparisons (N=3). The junction frequencies (Jfreq) of each sgmRNA were compared in 568 MHV-WT (blue) and MHV-ExoN(-) (orange) infected monolayers (C) and virions (D). 569 Error bars represent standard errors of the mean (SEM) (N = 3) and statistical 570 significance was determined by a 2-way ANOVA with multiple comparisons, * p <0.05, 571 **** p < 0.0001. (D) The percentages of sgmRNA and DVG junctions were compared in 572 MHV-WT (blue) and MHV-ExoN(-) (orange) infected monolayers (E) and virions (F). 573 Error bars represent SEM (N = 3). Statistical significance was determined by a 2in MHV-ExoN(-) are mapped across the genome and colored according to 578 their fold-change (red squares = decreased abundance, green circles = increased 579 abundance). See also Figures S4 and S5B, Tables S4-S5. 580 Direct RNA Nanopore sequencing of MHV full-length recombined RNA 582 molecules. Direct RNA Nanopore sequencing of MHV virion RNA. Full-length reads 583 were identified by bioinformatic filtering for reads containing the genomic termini. (A) 584 Genome coverage maps of full-length MHV-WT (blue) and MHV-ExoN(-) (orange) 585 Nanopore reads aligned to the MHV-A59 genome using minimap2. (B) Sashimi plot 586 visualizing junctions (arcs) in MHV-WT (blue) and MHV-ExoN(-) (orange). (C) Junctions 587 in reads containing only 2 discontinuous regions (1 junction) are mapped according to 588 genome position. The junction 5' site is mapped as the Start Position on the y-axis and 589 the 3' site is mapped as the Stop Position on the x-axis. Junctions are colored according 590 to their frequency in the population (log10(Frequency)). MHV-WT (low = blue, high = 591 cyan) and MHV-ExoN(-) (low = orange, high = yellow). (D) RNA molecule genetic 592 architectures with at least 3 supporting reads identified in both MHV-WT and MHV-593 ExoN(-) (yellow) and unique to MHV-WT (blue). There were no reads unique to MHV-594 represented by dashed lined. Canonical sgmRNA species are noted. The number of 597 reads supporting each species are noted (Count). See also

FIGREF8.text: Contact. Further information and requests for resources and reagents should be 601 directed to and will be fulfilled by the Lead Contact, Mark R. Denison 602 (mark.denison@vumc.org). 603 Materials Availability. This study did not generate new unique reagents. 604 Data and Code Availability. The datasets generated during this study are available at 605 the Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under BioProject accession numbers 606 PRJNA623001, PRNJA623016, PRJNA623285, PRJNA623325, PRJNA623312, 607 PRNJA623282, PRJNA623323, PRJNA623314, PRJNA623580, PRJNA623578. The in-608 house scripts utilized in this study are publicly available at 609 https://github.com/DenisonLabVU/rna-seq-pipeline. 610

FIGREF9.text: . DBT-9 cells were 613 originally obtained from Ralph Baric at University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill and were 614 maintained within 50 passages of this progenitor stock. Cells were maintained in 615 Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium (DMEM) (Gibco) supplemented with 10% fetal clone 616 serum (FCS) (Invitrogen), 100 U/mL penicillin and streptomycin (Gibco), and 0.25 617 µg/mL amphotericin B (Corning). Cercopithecus aethiops Vero CCL-81 cells maintained 618 in Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium (DMEM) (Gibco) supplemented to final 619 MERS-CoV-2 infection. Vero CCL-81 cells were obtained from ATCC. Vero E6 622 cells maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium (DMEM) (Gibco) supplemented 623 to final concentrations of 10% fetal calf serum (Gibco), 100 IU/ml penicillin (Mediatech), 624 100 mg/ml streptomycin (Mediatech), and 0.25 mg/ml amphotericin B (Mediatech) were 625 used for SARS-CoV-2 infections. Vero E6 cells were obtained from ATCC. 626 METHOD DETAILS 627 Viruses. All MHV work was performed using the recombinant WT strain MHV-A59 628 (GenBank accession number AY910861.1 (Yount et al., 2002)) at passage 4 and an 629 engineered ExoN(-) strain of MHV-A59 at passage 2. Experiments involving MERS-CoV 630 were conducted using the human EMC/2012 strain recovered from an infectious clone 631 (GenBank accession number JX869059.2) (Scobey et al., 2013). Experiments involving 632 SARS-CoV-2 were conducted with a passage 5 virus inoculum generated from a 633 Seattle, WA, USA COVID-19 patient (GenBank accession number MT020881.1). All 634 virus manipulations were performed under stringent BSL-3 laboratory conditions 635 according to strict protocols designed for safe and controlled handling of MERS-CoV 636 and SARS-CoV-2. 637 MHV isolation and virion purification. Subconfluent 150-cm 2 flasks were infected with 638 either MHV-A59 or MHV-ExoN(-) at an MOI of 0.01 PFU/cell. Supernatant was 639 harvested at either 16 hours post infection (MHV-A59) or 24 hours post infection (MHV-640ExoN(-)) when the monolayer was >95% fused and remained intact. Infection 641 supernatant was clarified by centrifugation at 1500 x g for 5 minutes at 4°C. Viral 642 for 16 hours. The viral pellet was resuspended in MSE buffer (10mM MOPS, pH 644 6.8; 150mM NaCl; 1 mM EDTA). Viral RNA was extracted using the TRIzol-LS reagent 645 according to manufacturer's protocols. RNA was quantified using the Qubit RNA HS 646 assay. Virion data in this paper is the result of three independent experiments 647 sequenced independently.648 MHV isolation from infected monolayers. Three subconfluent 150-cm 2 flasks of DBT-649 9 cells were infected with either MHV-WT or MHV-ExoN(-) at an MOI or 0.01 PFU/cell. 650 Monolayer was harvested at either 16 hpi (MHV-WT) or 24 hpi (MHV-ExoN(-)) when the 651 monolayer was >95% fused and >75% intact. RNA was extracted with TRIzol according 652 to manufacturer's protocols. Infected monolayer data in this paper is the result of three 653 independent experiments sequenced independently. 654 MERS-CoV infection. Three nearly confluent 25-cm 2 flasks of Vero CCL-81 cells were 655 infected with MERS-CoV at an MOI of 0.3 pfu/cell. Total infected cell lysates were 656 collected at 72 hpi with the monolayer < 50% intact. RNA was extracted in TRIzol 657 according to manufacturer's protocols. 658 SARS-CoV-2 infection. Five subconfluent 25-cm 2 flasks of Vero E6 cells were infected 659 at an MOI = 0.45 pfu/cell and cellular monolayers were harvested 60 hpi when the 660 monolayer was >90% fused. RNA was extracted in TRIzol according to manufacturer's 661 protocols. 662 Short-read Illumina RNA-sequencing of viral RNA. Next generation sequencing 663 (NGS) libraries were generated using 2 µg of RNA. RNA was submitted to Genewiz for 664 library preparation and sequencing. Briefly, after quality control, polyadenylated RNA 665 during library preparation. Isolated RNA was heat fragmented and libraries 666 were prepared for 2 x 250 nucleotide paired-end sequencing performed (Illumina). 667 Genewiz performed basecalling and read demultiplexing. 668 Direct RNA Nanopore sequencing. RNA from ultracentrifuge-purified virions was 669 prepared for direct RNA Nanopore sequencing on the Oxford Nanopore Technologies 670 MinION platform according to the manufacturer's protocols. Libraries were sequenced 671 on fresh MinION R9.4 flow-cells for 24 hours, or until the pore occupancy was under 672 20%. Virion RNA from three independent experiments was sequenced on three 673 separate flow cells for both MHV-WT and MHV-ExoN(-). MERS-CoV RNA from three 674 independent cultures was sequenced on three separate flow cells. SARS-CoV-2 RNA 675 isolated from three independent infections was sequenced on three separate flow cells. 676 QUANTIFICATION AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS 677 Illumina RNA-seq processing and alignment. Raw reads were processed by first 678 removing the Illumina TruSeq adapter using Trimmomatic (Bolger et al., 2014) 679 default settings (command line parameters java -jar trimmomatic.jar PE 680 sample_R1.fastq.gz sample_R2.fastq.gz output_paired_R1.fastq 681 output_unpaired_R1.fastq output_paired_R2.fastq 682 output_unpaired_R2_unpaired.fastq ILLUMINACLIP:TruSeq3-683 PE.fa:2:30:10 LEADING:3 TRAILING:3 SLIDINGIWINDOW:4:15 684 MINLEN:36). Reads shorter than 36 bp were removed and low-quality bases (Q score 685 < 30) were trimmed from read ends. The raw FASTQ files were aligned to the MHV-A59 686 genome (AY910861.1), the MERS-CoV genome (JX869059.2), and the SARS-CoV-2 687 genome (MT020881.1) using the Python2 script ViReMa (Viral Recombination Mapper) Routh and Johnson, 2014) using the command line parameters python2 ViReMa.py 689 reference_index input.fastq output.sam --OuputDir sample_virema/ 690 --OutputTag sample_virema -BED --MicroIndelLength 5. The sequence 691 alignment map (SAM) file was processed using the samtools (Li et al., 2009) suite to 692 calculate nucleotide depth at each position in a sorted binary alignment map (BAM) file 693 (using command line parameters samtools depth -a -m 0 694 sample_virema.sorted.bam > sample_virema.coverage). 695 Recombination junction analysis. Recombination junction frequency (Jfreq) was 696 calculated by comparing the number of nucleotides in detected recombination junctions 697 to the total number of mapped nucleotides in a library. Nucleotides in detected 698 recombination junctions were quantified as a sum of nucleotide depth reported at each 699 junction in the BED file generated by ViReMa. Total nucleotides mapped to the MHV-700 A59 genome were quantified as a sum of nucleotide depth at each position across the 701 genome in the tab-delineated text file generated by the samtools. Jfreq was reported as 702 junctions per 10 4 nucleotides sequenced. Mean Jfreq values were compared between 703 MHV-WT and MHV-ExoN(-) and statistical significance determined by an unpaired 704 student's t-test. Junctions were mapped across the genome according to their start (5') 705 and stop (3') positions. These junctions were first filtered in the forward (5' à 3') 706 direction using the dpylr package (RStudio). The frequency of each junction was 707 calculated by comparing the depth of the unique junction to the total number of 708 nucleotides in all detected junctions in a library. Junctions were plotted according to the 709 genomic position and colored according to log10 of the frequency using ggplot2 in 710 was calculated at each genomic position by dividing the 712 number of nucleotides in any junction mapping to the position divided by the total 713 number of nucleotides sequenced at the position. Mean recombination frequencies 714 were compared between MHV-WT and MHV-ExoN(-) for three independent sequencing 715 experiments by a two-way ANOVA statistical analysis with multiple comparisons. 716 Identification of sgmRNA and DVG junctions. Forward recombination junctions were 717 classified as either canonical sgmRNA junctions or DVG junctions based on the position 718 of their junction sites and filtered in Microsoft Excel. Briefly, junction start sites were 719 filtered to those positioned between nucleotide 62 -72 in the genome. The stop sites 720 were then filtered for those positioned within each respective sgmRNA TRS. sgmRNA 721 frequency was calculated by dividing the sum of the depth of all junctions corresponding 722 to an individual sgmRNA by the total number of mapped nucleotides at each position. 723 The filtered sgmRNA junctions were compiled and DVG junctions were filtered in 724 RStudio by performing an exclusionary anti_join() using dplyr. DVG junctions 725 were filtered in the forward direction. The percentage of sgmRNA and DVG junctions 726 was calculated by comparing the depth of all filtered sgmRNA or DVG junctions to the 727 sum of all detected forward junctions. Mean percent sgmRNA and DVG was compared 728 between three independent sequencing experiments in virion RNA. Statistical 729 significance was determined by a 2-way ANOVA test with multiple comparisons. 730 Differential abundance of junctions. To compare the abundance of junctions in MHV-731 A59 and MHV-ExoN(-), the ViReMa output list of junctions was analyzed by in-house 732 scripts (https://github.com/DenisonLabVU) and the R package DESeq2 (Love et al., 733 2014). Junctions significantly up-or down-regulated in MHV-ExoN(-) were visualized 734 bioinfokit (Bedre, 2020) and further mapped according to their genomic 735 positions. Statistical significance was determined by the p-value of each junction 736 calculated by the DESeq2 package in RStudio and junctions with a significant alteration 737 of abundance in MHV-ExoN(-) compared to MHV-WT were visualized as either red or 738 green in the graph generated by bioinfokit. 739 Direct RNA Nanopore alignment and analysis. Live basecalling was performed by 740 Guppy in MinKNOW. Run statistics were generated from each sequencing experiment by 741 NanoPlot (De Coster et al., 2018). Pass reads from all three experiments were 742 concatenated for each virus and aligned to the genome using minimap2 (Li, 2018) and 743 FLAIR (Full Length Alternative Isoforms of RNA) (Tang et al., 2018) to generate 744 alignment files and BED files listing deletions detected in each sequenced RNA 745 molecule. Both BAM and BED files were filtered for full length molecules using 746 samtools and Microsoft Excel, respectively. Full-length MHV molecules were defined 747 as encoding coverage at positions 71 and 31034, representing the canonical TRS-L and 748 beginning of the 3' UTR required for replication. Because no TRS sequences have been 749 experimentally confirmed in either MERS-CoV or SARS-CoV-2, we filtered both 750 datasets for those that included any sequence of the 5' UTR and 3' UTR of the 751 respective viruses. BED files generated by the flair align module were parsed based on 752 the number of junctions were identified. Nanopore reads containing only 1 junction were 753 identified using Microsoft Excel and unique junctions were quantified in RStudio using 754 base-R functions. Sequencing coverage maps were generated from samtools depth 755 analysis of filtered BAM files. All junctions present in sequenced libraries were mapped 756 in Sashimi plots generated by the Integrated Genome Viewer (IGV) (Robinson et al., present in full-length MHV RNA molecules with a single deletion were 758 mapped according to their genomic positions as previously described. The genetic 759 architectures of full-length RNA molecules sequenced by direct RNA Nanopore 760 sequencing were visualized by filtering RNA molecules for at least 3 supporting reads. 761 Low frequency variants were removed from this analysis. 762 763 Table S3. Direct RNA Nanopore read isoforms, related to Figures 2 and 5. Direct 764 RNA Nanopore reads aligning to viral genome by minimap2. Individual reads are listed 765 by read name. Genomic positions of read alignment are listed ("Read Start", "Read 766 Stop"). Read segments aligning to the genome are noted ("# Segments") and start 767 positions and aligned segment legnths listed ("Segment Start", "Segment Length"). 768 Table S4. Genomic positions with significantly altered positional recombination 769 frequency in MHV-ExoN(-) infected monolayer and virion RNA compared to MHV-770 WT, related to Figure 4. Positions with significantly altered recombination frequency in 771 MHV-ExoN(-) infected monolayer RNA compared to MHV-WT and in MHV-ExoN(-) 772 virion RNA compared to MHV-WT as determined by a 2-way ANOVA with multiple 773 comparisons are listed. Genomic regions are noted. (N = 3 for each infected cell and 774 virion RNA samples) 775 Table S5. Differential abundance of recombination junctions in MHV-ExoN(-) 776 infected monolayer compared to MHV-WT, related to Figure 4. Junctions with 777 altered abundance in MHV-ExoN(-) infected monolayer RNA compared to MHV-WT and 778 in MHV-ExoN(-) virion RNA compared to MHV-WT are listed. P-values calculated by 779 DESeq2. (N = 3 for each infected monolayer and virion RNA samples)
